name: Chat UI
description: Conversational, natural language based interfaces that allow users to simply talk to a product or service. Users will able to request money to be sent or balances to be displayed via text or voice. Chat interfaces may exist as applications inside existing messaging platforms.
label: A1

name: International Remittance
description: Much of the cost associated with remittances comes in the form of physical kiosks that accept and distribute cash and in the regulatory environment. Leveraging blockchain, international remittances can be made possible at a fraction of the cost of current methods greatly benefitting many people in underbanked economies.
label: B1

name: Branded Currency
description: Individual organizations and companies will create and mint their own digital currencies that are tradable and interoperable. The new nature of these currencies will allow them to be managed the way people currently manage their money (setting budgets, investing, loaning).
label: B1

name: Private Blockchain
description: Distributed ledger databases that are specific to a single company or consortium. These blockchains have controlled "write-permissions" that will allow companies such as banks or other financial institutions to utilize the efficiencies of blockchain without giving up total control.
label: E1

name: Crypto-Escrow
description: Allows the transfer of assets between two independent blockchains or crypto-currencies. This new model removes the need for each party to trust the market maker not to steal or loose the assets. Because of this, legal contracts are not needed to mediate the exchange.
label: B1

name: Blockchain Prediction Market
description: Uses the power of the crowd to forecast and predict events by allowing for the buying and selling of shares in a specific outcome. Enabled by decentralized public ledgers, event forecasting by consensus can have effects on everything from finance to healthcare to governance.
label: D1

name: Asset Digitization
description: Using to little to no Bitcoin, one can create assets and trade them in a peer-to-peer fashion. In addition to providing efficiencies and security to existing asset classes, this opens up the ability to create entirely new types of digital assets for everything from concert tickets to gift card vouchers.
label: B1

name: Quantum Encryption
description: Makes digital information and transactions ultra-secure. In a world where nefarious hackers have access to quantum computers, a quantum based encryption algorithm will be needed. These algorithms use the unique keys that leverage quantum particle superpositions.
label: E1

name: Crypto-Identity
description: Cryptographically secure identification records that allow for users to control the transmission and visibility of data to third parties. Enabled by the blockchain, crypto-ID also allows for a single identity source to serve as the user login for a number of applications eliminating redundancies across databases and companies. Using a combination of cryptography and a blockchain ledger, an ID can be verified in real time by anyone.
label: E1

name: Smart Contract
description: Executable and automatically enforceable contracts that need no third party. Property that is embedded with a digital component such as a smart appliance can use and enforce smart contracts without the need for authorization by a user for example. Because these digital contracts are  publicly viewable and auditable, and distributed in blockchain, they are able to self-regulate and execute automatically if their programmed conditions are met.
label: E1

name: Cognitive Financial Advice
description: Systems that can provide financial advice by developing deep domain insights and translating this information in a user friendly way. Additionally, these systems can contextualize insights with regard to a specific user's information. These systems learn and grow over time and are far more powerful in the mining of "big data" than traditional systems.
label: A1

name: Digital Wallet
description: Software wallets today already do more than their leather counterparts; they are streamlining transactions, and moving a host of new currencies and economies. Smartphones can use scanning technology to scan 2D barcodes, NFC components to make payments, and location services to develop relationships with nearby merchants. Expect a crop of apps and services that let you store, synchronise, track and share the contents of your wallet across devices, and let you pay in a multitude of units from Google Credits, Canadian Cryptodollars to Facebook shares.
label: B1

name: Sharing Economy
description: Powered by network technologies and peer communities, collaborative consumption is a new economic model geared toward increasing access, not ownership. Through online platforms, consumers are able to lend, swap, barter, share and gift products or services on an unprecedented scale. Massive networks for social lending, car sharing and peer-to-peer travel have already established themselves as major economic forces for sustainability.
label: D1

name: Peer-To-Peer Economy
description: Peer-to-peer economies occur when the production, transaction and consumption of goods happen between individuals, not companies, allowing small suppliers to compete with traditional providers of goods or services. These kind of transactions aren't new, but the internet has allowed more people to connect and trade in convenient and trustworthy markets, using tools such as search and matching algorithms, pricing, and reputation systems.
label: B1

name: Universal Card
description: Allows people to combine an unlimited number of debit, credit and loyalty cards into one physical payment card. The original card details of the holder are never revealed to any merchant, online or in-store. It also connects to the users smartphone through a secure Bluetooth channel, which is meant to prevent unauthorised people from being able to use it or transmit information from it without access to the user’s smartphone.
label: B1

name: Crowdfunding
description: Crowdfunding draws on the power of crowds and networks to solicit investments, usually in small amounts, for particular projects. It is a departure from the traditional model of investment, which relies on a select investor or firm. Though not a new concept, the internet and its platforms has expanded and accelerated funding to extraordinary degree. Beyond providing more access to resources, it reduces costs, increases engagement, shifts mindsets on organisational possibilities and empowers small endeavours.
label: D1

name: Social Sentiment Analysis
description: The mining of subjective information that is being published across the internet (especially on social media). Determine if anything from a document to a tweet is positive, negative, or neutral with respect to an entity and if that content will have an affect on things such as investor confidence.
label: D1

name: BitCoin Miner
description: Computers equipped with native hardware or software which enables access to streams of bitcoin, making it easier for people without programming skills to participate in the mining process of the blockchain. This facilitation has the potential to globalize cryptocurrencies faster, and to exponentiate their usage.
label: B1

name: Universal Exchange Rate
description: Currency-exchange is an enormous business with trillions of dollars crossing borders each year, and historically an extremely inefficient and opaque one. New peer-to-peer platforms for transferring money abroad for a lower cost than currently offered by banks are starting to change that scenario. It saves customers on the hidden costs of currency transactions by using the mid-market rate – that is the mid-point between the buy and sell price – which generally isn’t available to retail customers.
label: B1

name: AI Assistant
description: Populating any device connected to the internet and learning through a variety of inputs such as conversations, preferences and habits, these personal assistants will be able to predict and answer tasks as if their owner was doing it. From shopping to scheduling meetings, these context-aware intelligent AI will be hyper personal.
label: A1

name: Blockchain
description: Online database that stores information across a network of personal computers, making it not just decentralized but distributed. This means no central company or person owns the database, yet everyone in the network can use and help run it, but not tamper with it. The most popular use of this technology today is bitcoin, but is just the beginning. In the future, blockchains that manage and verify online data will launch companies entirely run by algorithms, help us protect our online identities, and track the billions of devices on the Internet of Things.
label: E1

name: Collaborative B2B Commerce
description: Real-time data platforms which records information of each step of supply chains in order to show stakeholders their current state. By using a blockchain logic, it is possible to track any asset with their unique identification key. This new logic of open and accessible information have the potential to revolutionize how brands and companies deal with their whole supply ecosystem.
label: D1

name: Cryptocurrency Insurance
description: Although the blockchain network is almost incorruptible, the same cannot be said about its users - cryptocurrency are prone to be stolen and fraud. In order to ensure the safety of these digital coins, there will be a growing need of development of cybersecurity. Services which store safety for bitcoins also could offer insurance with a liability based on the fluctuating price of cryptocurrencies.
label: C1

name: Drone Insurance
description: Flying drones can be used for a huge variety of operations, and all these uses need commercial drone liability insurance because of the potential accidents which can happen. There will be the need for a seamless stream of data and automation of the policies, especially because of the paperwork and bureaucracy involved with this technology.  Pre-flight checklists, logbooks, post-flight checks - there is potential to deal with the standardization of insurance packages.
label: C1

name: Internet Of Things Insurance
description: As devices are increasingly more connected to the Internet, there will be a need from insurance companies to make "connected coverages". With the help of data gathered from IoT, it will be possible for insurers to identify trends and patterns in behavior, leveraging policies and pricing. It will be possible to analyze new information and cross-reference it with historical information and change their model from a reactive one, to a preventive model.
label: C1

name: Real-Time Micro Insurance
description: This type of service can be done as quickly as an online transaction, because it uses instantaneous data from an event in order to choose the best policy available for the insured. Features can be tailored to offer protection for the shortest period of time by mining both public and private data, creating personalized products on-the-go.
label: C1

name: Insurance Telematics
description: Telematics refers to devices (such as cars) which merges telecommunications and infomatics. For insurance companies, solutions such as a GPS connected directly to the internet, or sensors which collect data from the driver will enable tailored policies for each driver based on their risks and behavior. Further uses could be to improve security by calling the emergency right after an accident or fraud prevention.
label: C1

name: Blockchain Notary
description: Services that anonymously secure and store an online distributed proof of existence for any document. Documents or files are timestamped within the blockchain, but not stored inside it so it is impossible for them to be tampered or modified. This creates a 'digital footprint' easily traceable, adding a layer of security that proves data ownership without revealing actual data.
label: E1

name: Autonomous Organization
description: Financial entities without a centralized owner which work like a blockchain, running independently and paying for its own resources inside the cyberspace. After these organizations are scripted, they will be able to keep running alone and adapt by using computer deep learning. Because the autonomous organizations are powered by thousands of computers, they produce results of high reliability and security.
label: D1

name: Open-Source Investment Algorithm
description: Most investment algorithms are proprietary and managed by large investment firms. Following the volatility of the financial markets and loss of confidence in institutions, there has been a rise in platforms to drive open-source algorithms. Built by a community, they are constantly adapting and evolving. This could provide opportunities for traders to develop algorithms for their own needs, and quickly test new ideas in investments.
label: A1

name: Omniscient ATM
description: Working 24/7, futuristic ATMs will recognize its user with a set of biometrical sensors - being able to tell if the person making a transaction is tense or sad, and fire alerts depending on their status. There will be no need to use cards or pins, because the authentication will be completed entirely with biometric credentials. For people that are far away from a bank, live bank tellers via webcam or digital assistants will help with any needs, making a trip to the agency practically unnecessary.
label: E1

name: Data-Mining Credit Scoring Model
description: In order to provide instantaneous credit score assessment, search algorithms will be able to look into big data to understand borrowers' credit worthiness. . By using information which exceeds payment history, such as online reputation, professional connections or demographic characteristics, it will be possible to predict risks related to credit obligations.
label: C1

name: Streamlined Payment
description: Without asking for a credit card or money, services that handle customers' payments and charge only after the service is concluded or the product sucessfully shipped could potentially augment conversion rates for many digital services. As credit assessment gets more reliable and people without financial institutions get access to the internet, the need for a simplistic and reliable form of payment will drive the need for e-commerces to look for alternatives from direct online payment.
label: B1

name: Big Data Optmization
description: By processing large volumes of data, financial institutions will be able to leverage huge amounts of information in order to gather insights about their operations. Big data usage have the potential to transform business and market operations if the analytics tools used are integrated within management decisions.
label: A1

name: Metasearch AI
description: As the number of offers for pretty much any type of product or service increases, the use of aggregators in order to search for the best price/quality will potentially become the first place to go instead of the native place. The search tool will use the personal information data from the user and match it with the search engine's data in order to get results which will satisfy both the buyer and the seller. Results will be taylored especifically for the needs of each user, and can be modified using the configurations.
label: A1

name: Banking Omnichannel
description: By integrating financial services into any device connected to the internet, a bank could be available to the customer on a variety of touchpoints, instead of exclusive ones (such as a ATM or an agency). Devices such as wearables or appliances with sensor technology could improve the banking experience by giving more data. Consumers could be able to perform their transactions in any device they have available and their device could respond depending on their context.
label: B1

name: Latency Intelligence Monitoring Software
description: A software able to quantify sources of latency for capital markets industry, helping customers to minimize latency in trade execution and market data flow in real-time. As trading becomes more accurate and change faster in a connected world, there will be a need for transactions with highly accurate nanosecond time-stamping technology.
label: D1

name: Physiological Bank
description: As health tracking becomes easier and cheaper with the use of wearables and smart sensors, the amount of information it is possible to gather from someone increases. By connecting well being and health with financial services, it would be possible to provide for customers rewards for keeping healthy habits or to give spending advices based on their overall physiological needs. As for consuming habits, data could be synced with habits in order to understand how hormones impacts purchasing decisions, for example.
label: A1

name: Robo-Viser
description: Management softwares will make automated investment much cheaper and easier. By managing the users' investment account 24/7, robo advisors will choose which portfolio is best depending on personal financial history. By using big data and real time analytics, money can be automatically invested or withdrawn as the market or conditions change. Investing, tax optimization, reinvesting - everything can be tailored specifically to the behavior and the needs of the investor.
label: A1

name: Real Time Pricing
description: By harnessing the data available from sets such as customer interactions, competitors pricing or even availability of inventory, retailers will be able to set algorithms to change prices in real time or even charge differently to each buyer. Systematic pricing will make online retailers charge by behavior alongside other economical factors.
label: B1

name: Identity Wearable
description: Accessories and clothing connected to the cloud and to other applications have the potential to become an authenticator for transactions, especially when connected to unique biometric authenticators such as heart beat or voice. Near field communication (NFC), location and scanning technologies on smartphones are powering contactless in-store transactions. tap their phone on a NFC machine, or check in with a nearby merchant to autorize transactions from linked accounts. This streamlines payment systems, reduces infrastructure and lowers costs. Credentials can be easily programmed into the wearables and because the communication between devices is cryptographed, it is possible to perform payments or enable access using simply bluetooth or proximity.
label: E1

name: Equity Crowdfunding
description: Startups, companies and creators are opening up their shares, even before they become public, in order to raise capital faster. With new regulations, it will become easier for non-accredited investors own part of companies and projects, choosing how much they want and can invest. The value of the shares follows the venture’s growth, creating a mutual relationship based on success with the shareholders.  As this type of funding becomes global, interesting ideas will sprout much faster based on how interesting they are to the community.
label: D1

name: Healthy Lifestyle Coach
description: By gathering personal data and health stats from wearables or sensors, artificial intelligence have the potential to replicate live coaches or doctors, giving personalized advices and tips to users in order for them to improve healthy behaviors that could affect various types of insurance policies or help inform financial behavior. This type of coach can permeate a variety of devices, from simple smartphones to complex virtual-reality systems, enabling the general population access to affordable and easy wellness education.
label: A1

name: Sharing Economy Insurance
description: As the number of users of sharing economy services grow, these companies will need to offer protection and liability insurance to their stakeholders, in order to keep their services stable and sheltered from unexpected outcomes. Primary coverage should protect both parties involved in a transaction, so no side is left harmed in a negotiation.
label: D1

name: Mutual Authentication Fraud-Proof Server
description: Malware and hackers which target banks and digital services could be stopped by using a combination of offline and online security methods. One of the techniques with the biggest potential for security could be the  isolation of the server through virtualization or quantum key distribution. As security improves, it will become harder for fraudsters to avoid the secure barries done physically and digitally.
label: E1

name: Emotional Money
description: As financial services becomes more digitized, it will be easier to sync it with more layers of data, such as an avatar or a virtual assistant. This way, this type of services could give advice depending on the personal necessities of each user, looking for their overall financial status. Money which exhibited intelligence and emotion, and acted upon its use depending on their context could improve decision-making processes of buying or spending.
label: A1

name: Ethical AI
description: Policies written by computers have the potential to adapt their algorithms depending on the background or necessities of the user, such as financial needs, making personalized experiences. With machine learning, the policies or contracts have the potential to evolve as their decisions are inspected by a crowd of specialists. Ethical values such as responsibility, transparency, auditability, incorruptibility can be thought as algorithimic and programmed to work as such.
label: A1

name: Peer To Peer Lending
description: Online platforms and marketplaces which bypass banks by matching up lenders with individuals or small businesses that need to borrow money. These platforms are data-driven, and are able to check for the financial status of a borrower in minutes, approving or disapproving the loan instantly. The whole process is automated, creating a whole ecosystem of circulating capital.
label: D1

name: Unbundled Insurance Products
description: New insurance carries which provide quick, event-related insurance are going to disrupt the market by saving money to customers because of its reduced comprehensiveness. For example, pay-per-mile car insurance or even disease health insurance. Transactions can be done entirely online, making it no-touch or low-touch - and with the use of sensors or wearables, it will be even easier to make the process as precise as needed.
label: C1

name: Decentralized Document Notary
description: Powered by blockchain databases, documents can now be certified and verified using cryptography rather than by a third party. This will streamline the process and combat fraud reducing the overhead on traditional banking.
label: E1

name: AI Banker
description: Instead of an account being run by a personal banker, decisions have the potential to be done directly by artificial intelligence. By analyzing not only  banking history, but all the personal data about a user, AI can tailor banking experiences and offer personalized financial products. The whole process can be automated, as the digital banker have the potential to improve standardization of process workflow and reduce error rates.
label: A1

name: Algorithm Marketplace
description: Most organisations can’t afford a team of highly-paid developers with unlimited time to create, test and refine their algorithms and process data. As a result, data competitions have been organised first and now communities of developers that have started offering up their algorithms for sale in dedicated marketplaces.
label: D1

name: Attention Economy
description: We've turned a corner toward an economy where an increasing number of workers are no longer involved directly in the production, transportation, and distribution of material goods, but instead earn their living managing or dealing with information in some form. Since information is abundant, but attention to it isn't, the last one can be transformed into capital when it's paid, spent, given, taken or transacted, creating a new type of economy, typical from the cyberspace.
label: B1

name: Autonomous Device
description: Devices that are connected to the cloud but run their own software, collect and mine their own data, and make decisions in real-time rather than simply being displays of information. Autonomous devices can conduct their own transactions and be independent profit centers as well, for example a smart home power supply may buy and sell energy as it is needed.
label: C1

name: Behavioural Money
description: Financial services and smart products which use predictive analytics learned from big data could find patterns in user behaviour in order to tailor experiences on an individual level. This way, money could adapt to customer's needs and context, and also be trackable because of their unique habits - making it impossible to suffer fraud or to be stolen.
label: A1

name: Blackbox Algorithmic Trading
description: Stock trading based on algorithms with predefined buy and sell conditions. The algorithms used in this trading method allow traders to trade at volumes and speeds impossible for humans. Many traders have been using prebuilt algorithms to compensate for their lack of trading industry knowledge.
label: A1

name: Compliance As A Service
description: Companies working in heavily regulated industries such as financial services will outsource their compliance to cloud-based third parties. An increasing number of data breaches and hacks are also causing a constantly shifting regulatory environment meaning that it will become a full time business just managing the legal side of holding customer data.
label: C1

name: Crypto-Currency Debit Card
description: Helping to bridge the gap between fiat currency and crypto-currency, these cards will allow crypto-accounts to operate within the traditional payment infrastructure. Cards may support a number of different currency types and will function the same as traditional debit cards, converting currencies on the backend.
label: B1

name: Cyber Insurance
description: The growing threat of cyber attacks has created a need for this new class of insurance. Cyber insurance protects companies against hanks and data breaches that are not typically covered under Commercial General Liability policies. Cyber Insurance will become a must for any company dealing with digital transactions and storing customer data.
label: E1

name: Digital Security Trading
description: Trades of assets such as shares are settled by peer confirmation using blockchains. This cuts down on much of the overhead involved in regulating and mediating these trades by cutting out the need for auditors and clearinghouses. This in turn gives more access to users wishing to trade shares and greatly increases the speed and volume of transactions.
label: D1

name: Hypermedia Distribution Protocol
description: Enables the creation of completely distributed applications. Connects all computing devices with a single shared system of files. This type of protocol could potentially replace HTTP and create permanent, distributed web where websites are not dependent on a central entity or host to continue existing.
label: D1

name: Identity Insurance
description: As cybercrimes become more common, companies and individuals will have to protect themselves against data security breaches. Unique identifications and digital information will converge between devices and services in a exponential speed, so insurance against loss or theft of this type of data will also have an increased importance.
label: C1

name: Intention Economy
description: An economy in which demand will drive supply far more directly, efficiently, and compellingly than ever before, where vendors must respond to the actual intentions of customers instead of vying for the attention of many. Driven by the use of analytics and big data, business will offer products and services for specific personal needs stored in the cloud.
label: B1

name: Live Spending Broadcast
description: By syncing credit cards or bitcoins to social media, people will be able to broadcast what they are spending, requesting feedback to their network or simply showcasing their purchases. This could lead to behavioral changes towards what should be bought or not, depending on what people want to share.
label: A1

name: Nano-Payment
description: Payments below the traditional denominational thresholds. These payments are typically fractions of a cent. New technologies have reduced friction payments and reduced costs in processing now making a new class payment equitable. Nano-costs could be appended to social media likes, advertisement clicks, and the sending of emails among other use cases.
label: D1

name: Online Only Bank
description: A model conceived in the mid-90s for lower operational costs. This enables higher interest rates, lower fees and minimum requirements. Based online, they can problem-solve and innovate easily with technology – deposits are done via smartphone photos and customer service is available immediately through online chatting. This model will prevail over traditional banking.
label: B1

name: Online-Only Insurance Company
description: By selling all its products online along with handling claims, this new breed of companies aim to reshape traditional insurance by applying internet thinking across the insurance value chain from product design to claims servicing. They use, for example, big data and analytics support to ensure accurate product pricing and risk control. Furthermore, this online model has lower operating and distribution costs.
label: C1

name: Open Data Analytics
description: As technology enables more real-time access to more data, there ismore opportunity for analysis and improved decision-making. A raft of applications have emerged to evaluate transaction patterns, anticipate outcomes and progress. Individuals will be able to measure themselves against large swaths of the population and have a clearer understanding of their position. Soon, personal related to income, spending and debt, will transition to become applications.
label: A1

name: Peer To Peer Insurance
description: By disrupting the business model of insurance companies, which normally gain from denying claims, peer to peer insurance will pool insurance premiums with small groups of policy holders.  Distribution of funds, claims records keeping, etc are handled by smart contracts and the insurance "company" functions as a decentralized autonomous corporation on the blockchain. By using behavioral science in order to decrease fraud, any money left at the end of the policy period is refunded and  larger reinsurers provide backup in case damages exceed available funds.  Peer-to-peer insurance is the sharing economy model applied to insurance.
label: D1

name: Quantum Cash
description: Physical monetary notes that are either embedded with or linked to special quantum particles. These particles allow each note to have a unique unforgeable attribute making the notes impossible to counterfeit.
label: E1

name: Secure-Adaptive Architecture
description: With more digital businesses come more hackers, and with the birth of a new threat landscape we're seeing the death of antivirus software. A new type of security tools will be available to go on the offensive, leveraging predictive modeling, allowing apps to protect themselves for example.
label: E1

name: Self-Driving Car Insurance
description: New insurance models will be needed for self-driving cars, in order to to allow for compensation from auto accidents. New paradigms will be needed to be incorporated in policies such as: manufacturer no-fault compensation, increased price for complex components, decreased automobile ownership regulatory permissions and data management.
label: C1

name: Selfie Pay
description: As people become more mobile, and automation and digital technologies more pervasive, security becomes increasingly important. Online services migrate towards two-step authentication, instead of only passwords, whereas identity documents include biometric data. New wave of such technologies, relying on face recognition, found its way into payments, border agencies and automated access systems. All in order to facilitate the flow of people and data, without compromising security.
label: E1

name: Side-Chain
description: A specific type of blockchain that operates with other blockchains. Users of one blockchain can effectively leverage the benefits or features of another blockchain without needing to use the other blockchains native tokens. Side chains also allow developers to create new blockchains with new features that utilize the scale of other blockchains without compromising them.
label: D1

name: Smart Assets
description: Connected appliances and other enterprise assets that have the ability to monitor themselves. This monitoring allows the devices to make decisions based on data such as reordering toner before it runs too low based on previous consumption habits or scheduling maintenance checks when it detects a certain probability of potential compromise. Devices will be given the ability to manage a financial account in order to pay for their consumables and services.
label: C1

name: Smart-Bond
description: Self-paying financial instruments that have automated risk-free interest rates and payment streams. These instruments, being facilitated by smart-contracts, eliminate the need for third parties such as Central Counter Parties, Central Security Depositories, Custodian Banks and more, reducing costs associated with trading and distribution.
label: A1

name: Social Credit
description: An IT-based mechanism similar to credit rating has been proposed for evaluation of citizens' demeanor. Certain online behaviors, such as criticizing the government online, buying foreign products or socializing with "fringe elements", could be penalized by delaying paperwork, restricting access to jobs or reducing internet speeds.
label: D1

name: Triple-Entry Accounting
description: An alternative to double-entry bookkeeping where a transaction is recorded in three locations: the buyer's book, the seller's book, and a cryptographically secure third book. Triple-entry accounting solves the problem of being able to trust an given entity's books, eliminating the need for auditing.
label: E1

name: Ultra-Secure Smartphone
description: Smartphones that provide not only end-to-end data encryption but also a variety of other security measures such as voice encryption, location masking, microphone jamming, etc. This technology will become a must for high-profile business people who conduct much of their business from their phones and across internet connections from a range of less developed regions where security is more vulnerable.
label: E1

name: Video Appraisal
description: Insurance companies will be able to settle claims faster by appraising the damage via video. Customers will be able to talk to a virtual or live assistant in real time, saving both the insurer and the insured time and travel. Doubts and next steps can be discussed instantly, and the claimant will be able to get an electronic payment to settle the claim without the bureaucracy.
label: C1

name: Voice ID Security
description: With a rise in conversational interfacing in the form of digital personal assistants such as Siri, Cortana, and others, voice as an interaction medium is growing. With this comes the ability to ID users, allow access, and authorize actions based on the unique identifiers in a users voice, seamlessly integrating the "log-in" experience into the product.
label: E1
